Peking

June 28, 1914

Dr. A. E. Stearns, 
Phillips Academy,

Andover, Mass.. 
My dear Dr. Stearns: -

Thank you very much for the catalogues 
you sent me. I am glad to tell you that I have persuadea 
five of our younger students to go to Andover to polish up 
their preparation for college. I can assure you that these 
boys will prove themselves efficient in their scholastic 
work. As you know, they were chosen to go to America by the 
late Mr. Tong Kaison in 1911 and have been detained so long 
on account of our poor financial condition in China. Since 
this is their fate, they have to be satisfied with what can 
not be helped. Now they are going to sail with us for America 
on August 15th, and you can well imagine how glad we are to 
sail together after a long unprofitable but inevitable delay 
during which so much has been lost both in our studies and 
in the development of our minds.

There will be eleven of these young boys 
going to America instead of fourteen which was the original 
number and their average age is about sixteen or seventeen. 
They have a good knowledge in Chinese and a fair one in West -
ern studies.

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter thanking Stearns for the course catalogues and reporting that of the 11 students attending Andover, 5 students (list enclosed) had been chosen by Mr. Tong Kaison in 1911, but the delay was due to strained financial conditions. The average age of the students is 16 or 17 and they are eager to study in America. [List: Hsueh Hsueh Hai, Huan Chi Yen, Lu Shou Chen, Li Kuo Chow, Van Han Tsen] He notes that President of Tsing Hua College, Y. Tsur, asked the Director of the Indemnity Fund Students, Mr. T.T. Wong, to make arrangements for the boys. He asks Stearns to write to Mr. Wong to apply for same and offers to follow through with the students plans to attend Andover. A party of 98 students is to visit San Francisco in September. He includes the Tientsin address of Mrs. Tong Kaison.
